summary: in the years to come, the development of small-size instruments for on-the-spot pathogen detection is expected to be an important segment of the POCT market. a few companies have launched self-test products for hepatitis and human immunodeficiency virus detection based on antibody–antigen interactions. a promising alternative would be the inherently simple and lost-cost electrochemical method. in 2004, Liu et al. (7) successfully demonstrated a fully integrated biochip for cell isolation and lysis, target amplification, as well as electrochemical amplicon detection. however, the design and fabrication of the chip involves many complicated steps. a single silicon–glass microchamber was used for multiple pathogen detection. a model system of E.coli and B.subtilis was used. the assay involves the following steps: sample preparation. silicon chip (thickness of 400 m) had two fluid injection holes (top side, diameter of 500 m, depth of 100 m) and a chamber (bottom side, length and width of 5 mm, depth of 325 m) etched by inductively coupled plasma/deep reactive ion etching (ICP/DRIE) process. thin-film platinum (100 nm) was patterned on top of silicon substrate as heater and temperature sensors. a mixture of 60 mM pyrrole, 20 M pyrrole-EC, and 0.1 M LiClO4 was introduced into the microchamber. the microchamber was then washed with deionized water and dried with nitrogen gas. oligonucleotide capture probe specific for B.subtilis amplicon was used. labeled with gold nanoparticles via biotin–avidin interaction. silver metal is electrocatalytically deposited onto gold nanoparticles. the silver stripping time to reach a potential of +0.65 V was taken as the sample signal. the number of cells stated was the amount being introduced into the microchamber. the results for the detection of the two model species are presented in Figure 6. oligonucleotide detection capture probes are immobilized in duplicate. it is recommended that each individual electrode in an electrode array has a specific capture probe. the more common chemical attachment (spotting) method cannot be used because all the active electrode surfaces are embedded within the same microchamber. electrodes B and C exhibit much higher fluorescence intensity than electrodes A and D, indicating the highly specific probe immobilization as well as hybridization offered by the electrochemical pyrrole-based attachment chemistry. the linkage between the immobilized capture probe and electrode surface must be strong enough to survive through the thermal cycling process. amplification, and product detection performed within the same microchamber. intact cells are first broken down by applying a high temperature (90°C) to free the genomic DNA. magnetic particles are used to isolate the specific genomes. the ability of this single microchamber to detect specific cell type is demonstrated by running a series of experiments with E.coli cells of different concentrations. Figure 5 gives a semi-log plot of the sample to background ratio against the number of cells in the sample. this result confirms the successful isolation of the genome with the magnetic particle-based approach. 103 cells for each species per sample were used in this microdevice platform. thermal cell lysis, magnetic particle-based target genome isolation, DNA amplification and electrochemical sequence-specific amplicons detection have been successfully implemented.
